info.caption: Continuous index of the degree of forest anthropogenic modification for the beginning of 2019

attributes.name: Forest Landscape Integrity Index
attributes.description:
### Overview  
  
The Forest Landscape Integrity Index (FLII) dataset describes the degree of anthropogenic forest modification as of the beginning of 2019. The dataset is global with 300 m resolution. The FLII was calculated from data covering forest extent, observed and inferred human pressures, and alterations in forest connectivity. 

  
  
Deforestation is a major environmental issue, but far less attention has been given to the degree of anthropogenic modification of remaining forests. Human modification of remaining forests reduces ecosystem integrity, diminishes many of the benefits that these remaining forests provide, and is potentially as significant as outright forest loss in determining overall environmental outcomes. Many global environmental agendas, including halting biodiversity loss, reversing land degradation, and limiting climate change, depend upon retaining forests with high ecological integrity, yet the scale and degree of forest modification remain poorly quantified and mapped. Mapping and monitoring forest modification globally will provide essential information for coordinated global, national, and local policy-making, planning, and action, to help nations and other stakeholders achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and implement other shared commitments.

  
  
Created by [47 forest experts from across the world](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-19493-3#author-information), the FLII offers a timely indicator of the status and management needs of Earth’s remaining forests, and demonstrates there has been a huge loss of forest integrity. Globally, only 17.4 million km2 of forest (40%) can be considered having high integrity and only 27% of this area is found in nationally-designated protected areas ([Grantham et al. 2020](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-19493-3)).
  
  
### Methodology  
  
To produce the Forest Landscape Integrity Index, four datasets were combined representing:
         1. forest extent
        2. ‘observed’ pressure from high impact, localized human activities for which spatial datasets exist, specifically: infrastructure, agriculture, and recent deforestation
3. ‘inferred’ pressure associated with edge effects, and other diffuse processes, (e.g. activities such as hunting and selective logging) modelled using proximity to observed pressures
4. anthropogenic changes in forest connectivity due to forest loss

  
  
These datasets were combined to produce an index score for each forest pixel (300m), with the highest scores reflecting the highest forest integrity, as of the start of 2019.For the full documentation, please see the accompanying article [Grantham et al. 2020](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-19493-3). 
  
  
### Additional Information  
  
For access to the full dataset and additional information, click on the “Learn more” button.  
  
### Visualizing the Data  
  
Our team reformatted this dataset before displaying it on Resource Watch. See the documentation on how Resource Watch retrieved the data on [Github](https://resourcewatch.org/data/explore/e044a0d7-b3d4-4612-9848-71322b1772cc).  
  
### Disclaimer  
  
Excerpts of this description page were taken from the source metadata. Resource Watch shows only a subset of the dataset. For access to the full dataset and additional information, click on the “Learn more” button.

info.name: Forest Landscape Integrity Index
info.functions: Forest condition as a continuous index determined by degree of anthropogenic modification
info.cautions:
- Levels of human modification mapped are conservative; for example, no fires are treated as anthropogenic (since in some systems many are natural), and the effects of climate change are not captured. 
  
  
- Not all effects from geographical variations in levels of governance are captured. Online tools are being developed to enable users to tailor the global assumptions, weights, and criteria (e.g. forest definitions, treatment of fire) to more local contexts. 
  
  
- Further caveats can be found in [Grantham et al. 2020](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-19493-3.pdf).
